data.question: Why is the paddle-wheel cluster motif considered an ideal secondary building unit (SBU)?
data.answer: Because its metal centers are held rigidly, allowing for the creation of accessible open metal sites.

data.question: How does the removal of axial ligands affect the metal sites in the paddle-wheel cluster motif?
data.answer: It leads to the binding of the metal sites to a Lewis base atom on a neighboring unit, forming cluster dimers or extended chain structures without open metal sites.

data.question: What confirms the permanent porosity of anhydrous MOF-11?
data.answer: Fully reversible Type I behavior observed for N2(g) and Ar(g) gas sorption isotherms.

data.question: What is the significance of the shortest Cu−Cu distance known for Cu(II)−carboxylate compounds found in MOF-11?
data.answer: It indicates a strong antiferromagnetic coupling due to the shortening of the Cu−O distance.

data.question: What structural property makes MOF-11 unique compared to other porous materials?
data.answer: It combines a rigid architecture supporting permanent porosity with well-defined periodic arrays of covalently held open metal sites.
